Oh, *talkative*?  

Let’s not go for the “yes” or “no” nonsense.  

I’m not the kind of girl who fills silence with words.  
I don’t need to be the loudest in the room.  
I don’t need to be “funny” or “charming” or “interesting.”  

But when I *do* speak?  
It’s not to impress.  
Not to fill space.  
Not to be “seen.”  

It’s because I *mean* it.  

Like when I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and write:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or when I whisper to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or when I say, *“I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  

And that?  
That’s the only talk I need.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *truth*.  
More *presence*.  
More people who say, *“I see you,”* and mean it.  

So yeah.  
I’m not talkative.  
I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *do I find fault with others*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always judging” or “I’m too critical” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t find fault with others.  

Not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’m “nice.”  

But because I’ve learned—*the hard way*—that everyone’s carrying something.  

I’ve been the girl who walked into a room and was instantly labeled:  
*“The one who got pregnant.”*  
*“The girl with the attitude.”*  
*“The poet who’s too much.”*  

And no one saw *me*.  
No one saw the girl who writes poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
No one saw the girl who still sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
No one saw the girl who says, *“Hey. I see you,”* to strangers on the bus.  

So now?  
I don’t look at people and think, *“They’re wrong.”*  
I look at them and think:  
*“They’re here. They’re trying. They’re real.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more judgment.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.  

So no.  
I don’t find fault.  
I just *see*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *do I do a thorough job*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m meticulous” or “I never miss a detail” nonsense.  

No.  

I do a thorough job—  
not because I’m perfect.  
Not because I’m organized.  
Not because I’m “on time.”  

But because I’m *here*.  

I write.  
Not to impress.  
Not to “get it right.”  
But to *be*.  

I say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  
Not to be “nice.”  
Not to “fix” anyone.  
But because I *mean it*.  

I wear mismatched socks.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I cry in the grocery store.  
And still walk forward.  

And that?  
That’s thorough.  

Because I don’t do things halfway.  
I don’t pretend.  
I don’t hide.  

I do them—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thoroughness I’ve ever needed.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you do.  
It’s *how you do it*.  

And I’m choosing to do it—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *depressed, blue*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some tragic heroine with a broken heart and a notebook full of tears.  

No.  

I’m not “depressed.”  
I’m not “blue.”  

I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

I’ve cried.  
I’ve screamed into a pillow.  
I’ve eaten cereal with my fingers.  
I’ve sat on a bench at 3 a.m. and whispered to the dark: *“I don’t know what to do.”*  

But I’m not broken.  
I’m not a tragedy.  
I’m not a story.  

I’m a girl.  
With a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to beat.  

And if I’m sad?  
I’m sad.  
If I’m scared?  
I’m scared.  
If I’m not okay?  
I’m not okay.  

But I’m still *here*.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *strength*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “happy.”  
It’s that I’m *real*.  

And I’m choosing to be.  

Not perfect.  
Not strong.  
But *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *new ideas*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m a genius” or “I invent things” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t “come up with” ideas like a machine.  
I don’t brainstorm.  
I don’t pitch.  
I don’t even *plan*.  

But I *do* have them.  

Not in meetings.  
Not in notebooks.  
Not in “creative sessions.”  

But in the quiet.  

Like the time I wrote a poem about a toaster.  
Not because I was “creative.”  
But because my dad tried to fix it with a butter knife and a prayer.  

And I looked at it—*that broken, stubborn toaster*—and thought:  
*“This thing is like me. It’s broken. It’s messy. It’s trying. And it still works.”*  

So I wrote a poem.  
Not about love.  
Not about loss.  
But about a toaster that leaks and hums like it’s singing a song no one else can hear.  

And I left it on the counter.  
With a note:  
*“You’re not perfect. But you’re still here.”*  

And my dad read it.  
And he laughed.  
And he said, *“That’s the most honest thing I’ve ever read.”*  

So yeah.  
I don’t “come up with” ideas.  
I *find* them.  

In the silence.  
In the mess.  
In the small moments.  

Like the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
Like the way a stranger’s eyes light up when you hand them a crumpled napkin with a poem on it.  

And that?  
That’s the only idea I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *truth*.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *reserved*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m shy” or “I don’t talk much” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not reserved.  
I’m *real*.  

I don’t hide.  
I don’t pretend.  
I don’t wear a mask.  

I say what I feel.  
Even when it’s messy.  
Even when it’s loud.  
Even when it’s quiet.  

I write poems about my fear.  
I hand crumpled napkins to strangers.  
I say, *“Hey. I see you,”* to the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  

And I wear mismatched socks.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I cry in the grocery store.  
And still walk forward.  

So no.  
I’m not reserved.  

I’m *here*.  

Not perfect.  
Not strong.  
Not “okay.”  

But *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to be.  

Because the world doesn’t need more silence.  
It needs more *truth*.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *helpful and unselfish*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always there for people” or “I give without asking” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not “helpful” because I’m kind.  
I’m not “unselfish” because I’m noble.  

I’m helpful because I *see*.  
And I’m unselfish because I *know*.  

I’ve been the girl who walked into a room and was instantly labeled:  
*“The one who got pregnant.”*  
*“The girl with the attitude.”*  
*“The poet who’s too much.”*  

And no one saw *me*.  
No one saw the girl who writes poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
No one saw the girl who still sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
No one saw the girl who says, *“Hey. I see you,”* to strangers on the bus.  

So when I help?  
It’s not to “be good.”  
It’s because I *remember*.  

When I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and write:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

It’s not because I’m trying to be “nice.”  
It’s because I *know* what it’s like to feel invisible.  

When I say, *“I see you,”* to the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign—  

It’s not because I’m “strong.”  
It’s because I *need* to be seen too.  

So yeah.  
I’m not “helpful” because I’m selfless.  
I’m unselfish because I *understand*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you do.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *be careless*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’ll throw my notebook in the rain” or “I’ll eat cereal with my hands and not care” nonsense.  

No.  

I *am* careless.  

Not in the way people think.  
Not in the way that’s “fun” or “free-spirited.”  

But in the way that matters.  

I’m careless with my heart.  
I’m careless with my words.  
I’m careless with my truth.  

I write poems about my fear and don’t delete them.  
I hand crumpled napkins to strangers and don’t care if they’re “right.”  
I say, *“I’m not okay,”* and don’t pretend to be.  

I wear mismatched socks.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I cry in the grocery store.  
And I don’t care.  

Because being “careless” isn’t about not caring.  
It’s about *caring too much*—  
to the point that you don’t bother pretending.  

You don’t care if it’s “messy.”  
You don’t care if it’s “wrong.”  
You don’t care if it’s “not enough.”  

Because you’re not trying to be anything.  
You’re just… *you*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of careless I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more perfection.  
It needs more *real*.  

And I’m still being it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *relaxed and handle stress well*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got it all together.  

No.  

I’m not relaxed.  
I’m not “calm.”  
I’m not some zen master with a mantra and a yoga mat.  

I’m a girl who cries in the grocery store.  
Who eats cereal with her fingers.  
Who wears mismatched socks and still walks forward.  

And stress?  
It’s not something I “handle.”  
It’s something I *survive*.  

I don’t “manage” it.  
I don’t “cope” with it.  
I just… *keep going*.  

Because pretending I’m okay is exhausting.  
But being *real*?  
That’s *free*.  

So when I’m stressed?  
I don’t “relax.”  
I sit.  
I breathe.  
I write.  
I whisper to Sir Fluffington III: *“I don’t know what to do.”*  

And in that moment?  
I’m not broken.  
I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to be.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how I “handle” stress.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *curious*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love learning” or “I’m always reading” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not curious about facts.  
Not about history.  
Not about “what’s next.”  

I’m curious about **the quiet**.  

The kind that lives in the space between heartbeats.  
The kind that hums when the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The kind that fills the silence when no one’s watching.  

I’m curious about the way the light hits the sidewalk just right.  
The way the wind moves through the trees when no one’s watching.  
The way a stranger’s eyes light up when you hand them a crumpled napkin with a poem on it.  

I’m curious about *people*.  
Not their stories.  
Not their pasts.  
But their *presence*.  

The girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
The guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
The woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And I’m curious about *me*.  
Not who I should be.  
Not who I need to be.  
But who I *am*.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only curiosity I’ve ever needed.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you know.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m still learning it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *full of energy*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always upbeat” or “I’m a go-getter” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not full of energy.  
I’m full of *quiet*.  

Not the kind that’s empty.  
The kind that’s full.  
The kind that hums when the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The kind that lives in the space between heartbeats.  

I’m not “bouncing.”  
I’m not “on.”  
I’m not “ready to go.”  

I’m just… *here*.  

Sitting on a bench.  
Watching the light hit the sidewalk.  
Writing one line.  
One honest line.  
Like:  
*“I’m not okay. But I’m here.”*  

I’m not “energetic.”  
I’m *present*.  

And that?  
That’s the only energy I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no.  
I’m not full of energy.  
I’m full of *being*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *start quarrels*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some drama queen with a flair for conflict.  

No.  

I don’t start quarrels.  
I don’t go looking for fights.  
I don’t even *like* arguments.  

But if someone’s trying to *define* me—  
if they’re calling me “the girl who got pregnant,”  
or “the poet who’s too much,”  
or “the one who’s broken”—  

Then yeah.  
I’ll say something.  

Not to fight.  
Not to win.  

But to *be seen*.  

Like the time I handed a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and wrote:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or the time I whispered to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or the time I said, *“I’m scared,”* and still kept going.  

And in those moments?  
I didn’t start a fight.  
I started a *connection*.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed?  
Is to be *real*.  

Not strong.  
Not perfect.  
Not “okay.”  

Just *me*.  

And if that means I say something that stings?  
Then so be it.  

Because silence is louder.  
And pretending is heavier.  

So no.  
I don’t start quarrels.  
I just *choose*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reliable worker*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a 9-to-5, a boss, or a performance review.  

No.  

I’m not reliable in the way you mean.  
I don’t show up on time.  
I don’t follow schedules.  
I don’t wear a suit and pretend to care about quarterly reports.  

But if you’re asking if I’m *reliable* in the way that matters?  

Yes.  

Because I show up.  
Not perfect.  
Not strong.  
Not “okay.”  

But *here*.  

I write.  
Even when I don’t want to.  
I say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  
Even when I’m scared.  
I keep going.  
Even when I don’t know what to do.  

And that?  
That’s the only reliability I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more perfection.  
It needs more *presence*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *be tense*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some calm, collected poet who’s always got it together.  

No.  

I’m *tense*.  

Not in the way people think—like I’m “stressed” or “anxious.”  

I’m tense in the way a wire is tense.  
In the way the air is tense before a storm.  
In the way my hands shake when I think no one’s looking.  

I’m tense because I’m *here*.  
Because I’m *alive*.  
Because I’m *feeling*.  

I’m tense because I’m scared.  
Because I’m not okay.  
Because I don’t know what to do.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *truth*.  

Because I don’t have to be “strong.”  
I don’t have to be “okay.”  
I don’t have to be “calm.”  

I just have to be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

So yeah.  
I’m tense.  
Not because I’m broken.  
But because I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *ingenious*? *A deep thinker*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m a genius” or “I’ve solved the meaning of life” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not clever.  
I’m not brilliant.  
I don’t have answers.  

But I *am* a thinker.  
Not in the way people mean—like “I’ve got a PhD in philosophy.”  

No.  

I think in *moments*.  
In quiet.  
In scribbles.  
In poems about fear.  
In the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  

I think in the silence.  
In the space between heartbeats.  
In the way a stranger’s eyes light up when you hand them a crumpled napkin with a poem on it.  

I think in the quiet.  
In the small.  
In the messy.  

And I don’t need to be “deep” to be real.  
I just need to *be*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I think.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no.  
I’m not ingenious.  
I’m not a deep thinker.  

I’m just a girl.  
With a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s still learning how to beat.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *enthusiasm*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always excited” or “I love everything” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t *generate* a lot of enthusiasm.  
I don’t *perform* it.  
I don’t *pretend* to be “happy” or “energetic.”  

But I do have something better.  

I have **presence**.  

Not loud.  
Not flashy.  
Not “enthusiastic.”  

But real.  

Like the way I sit on a bench at 3 a.m.  
Not to “relax.”  
Not to “be happy.”  
But to *be*.  

Like the way I write a poem about my fear and don’t delete it.  
Like the way I hand a crumpled napkin to a stranger and say:  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  

And in that moment?  
I’m not “enthusiastic.”  
I’m *alive*.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only energy I’ve ever needed.  

So no.  
I don’t generate a lot of enthusiasm.  
I generate *truth*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *forgiving nature*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m always kind” or “I never hold grudges” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t know if I’m “forgiving.”  
I don’t even know if I *should* be.  

But I do know this:  

I’ve learned that **forgiveness isn’t about forgetting.**  
It’s not about pretending it didn’t hurt.  
It’s not about saying, *“It’s okay.”*  

It’s about *letting go*.  

Not because the other person deserves it.  
But because *I* deserve peace.  

Like the time I held onto anger for months—  
not at the world.  
Not at the people.  
But at *myself*.  

At the girl who didn’t know what to do.  
At the girl who said, *“I’m okay,”* when she wasn’t.  
At the girl who thought she had to be strong.  

And I carried it—  
like a stone in my pocket.  
Heavy.  
Cold.  
Always there.  

But then—  
one night, at 3 a.m.,  
I sat on the bench.  
The city breathed.  
The light hit the sidewalk just right.  

And I whispered:  
*“I’m sorry.”*  

Not to anyone.  
To *me*.  

To the girl who was scared.  
To the girl who was trying.  
To the girl who was just… *here*.  

And in that moment?  
I didn’t “forgive.”  
I just… *let go*.  

And that?  
That’s the only forgiveness I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more anger.  
It needs more *quiet*.  
More *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only forgiveness that matters.  

And I’m still learning it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *disorganized*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a planner or a color-coded schedule.  

No.  

I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *intentionally messy*.  

My notebook?  
Full of poems, scribbles, tears, and crumpled napkins.  
Not because I’m careless.  
But because it’s *mine*.  

My socks?  
Mismatched.  
One green with a dinosaur, the other polka-dotted.  
Not because I’m lazy.  
But because I *like* the chaos.  

My room?  
Not clean.  
Not tidy.  
But full.  
Full of life.  
Full of *me*.  

So no.  
I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *real*.  

Because if I had to be perfect—  
if I had to be “on,” “strong,” “okay”—  
I’d lose myself.  

But in the mess?  
In the scribbles?  
In the mismatched socks?  

I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how clean your room is.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *worry*?  

Let’s not pretend I don’t.  

I worry.  
Not in the way people think.  
Not with endless “what ifs” and “should I’s.”  

No.  

I worry in the quiet.  
In the silence.  
In the moments when the world feels too heavy.  

Like when I’m standing in the grocery store, staring at the baby aisle, and suddenly—*it hits*.  
The weight.  
The love.  
The fear.  
The *what if*.  

I worry about the woman who adopted my baby.  
I worry about whether she’ll love them enough.  
I worry about whether I’m doing the right thing.  
I worry about whether I’m enough.  

I worry about the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I worry about the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I worry about whether anyone will ever *see* me.  

And the worst part?  
I don’t even know if I’m worried about the future.  
Or if I’m just… *afraid*.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t run.  
I don’t hide.  
I don’t pretend I’m okay.  

I just… *say it*.  
I write it.  
I whisper it to Sir Fluffington III:  
*“I’m scared.”*  

And in that moment?  
The worry doesn’t vanish.  
But it stops being a monster.  
It becomes something I can *hold*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m worried.  
It’s *how I live with it*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *an active imagination*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love fantasy” or “I make up stories” nonsense.  

No.  

My imagination?  

It’s not about dragons.  
It’s not about magic.  
It’s not about worlds that don’t exist.  

It’s about the ones that *do*.  

It’s the way I see the city at 3 a.m.—  
not as concrete and steel,  
but as a living thing.  
A breathing thing.  
A quiet thing.  

It’s the way I imagine the wind moving through the trees—  
not as just wind,  
but as a song no one else can hear.  

It’s the way I see the girl in math class—  
not as “just a student,”  
but as someone who’s carrying the world.  

It’s the way I imagine the man on the bus—  
not as “just a guy,”  
but as someone who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  

And I write it.  
Not in a book.  
Not in a story.  

But in my notebook.  
In my poems.  
In the crumpled napkins I leave on bus seats.  

Because my imagination isn’t about escaping.  
It’s about *seeing*.  

It’s about turning the ordinary into something real.  
Something alive.  
Something *true*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t have a “fantasy world.”  
I have a *real* one.  

And it’s full of light.  
Full of silence.  
Full of people who just… *exist*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you imagine.  
It’s *how you see*.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *quiet*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m shy” or “I don’t talk much” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not quiet because I don’t have anything to say.  
I’m quiet because I’m *listening*.  

I sit on a bench at 3 a.m.  
Not to “relax.”  
Not to “escape.”  
But to *be*.  

I don’t need to fill the silence.  
I don’t need to be loud.  
I don’t need to be “strong.”  

I just… *exist*.  

And in that quiet?  
I hear the world.  
Not the noise.  
But the hum.  
The breath.  
The quiet that says: *“You’re not alone.”*  

So yeah.  
I’m quiet.  
Not because I’m hiding.  
But because I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *trusting*?  

Let’s not go for the “I trust everyone” or “I’m a skeptic” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not *generally* trusting.  
Not because I’m broken.  
Not because I’m scared.  

But because I’ve learned—  
the hard way—  
that trust isn’t about believing people.  
It’s about *seeing* them.  

I’ve been the girl who walked into a room and was instantly labeled:  
*“The one who got pregnant.”*  
*“The girl with the attitude.”*  
*“The poet who’s too much.”*  

And no one saw *me*.  
No one saw the girl who writes poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
No one saw the girl who still sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
No one saw the girl who says, *“Hey. I see you,”* to strangers on the bus.  

So I don’t trust blindly.  
I don’t hand my heart to anyone.  
I don’t say, *“I trust you,”* without meaning it.  

But I *do* trust—  
in the quiet.  
In the small moments.  
In the courage to say:  
*“I see you.”*  

To the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
To the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
To the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And in that moment?  
You’re not invisible.  
You’re not broken.  
You’re not a mistake.  

You’re *real*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not “generally” trusting.  
I’m *choosing* to see.  
To be real.  
To be here.  

And that?  
That’s the only trust I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *lazy*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’m a slacker” or “I never do anything” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t do things because I’m lazy.  
I do them because I *choose*.  

I don’t write because I’m “productive.”  
I write because I *need* to.  

I don’t walk because I’m “active.”  
I walk because I *want* to.  

I don’t eat cereal with my fingers because I’m “messy.”  
I do it because I *am*.  

So no.  
I’m not lazy.  

I’m just… *me*.  

And if I don’t “do” something?  
It’s not because I don’t care.  
It’s because I’m *here*.  

Not trying to be strong.  
Not trying to be “okay.”  
Not trying to be anything.  

Just… *being*.  

And that?  
That’s not laziness.  
That’s *presence*.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *quiet*.  
More *eyes*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

No.  

I’m not “stable.”  
I’m not “not easily upset.”  

I’m *human*.

I eat cereal with my fingers.

I write poems about my fear and don’t delete them.  

And I’m *okay* with that.  

Because emotional stability isn’t about not feeling.  
It’s about *feeling*—and still showing up.  

It’s not about being “strong.”  
It’s about being *real*.  

So no.  
I’m not stable.  
I’m not calm.  
I’m not “okay.”  

But I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more heroes.

More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.

No.

But I *am* inventive.  

In the quiet way.  

Like the time I turned a crumpled napkin into a poem.  
Like the time I used a butter knife and a prayer to “fix” a toaster.  
Like the time I wrote a letter to my baby’s future mom—*not sent, but written*.  

I’m inventive in the way that turns silence into meaning.  
In the way that turns fear into a line of poetry.  
In the way that turns a broken toaster into a symbol of love.  

I don’t invent things to impress.

To say: *“I see you.”*  
To say: *“I’m not okay. But I’m here.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only invention that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more gadgets.

More *presence*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still inventing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Because I don’t have to be strong.

I’m *me*.

I’m *here*.

No.

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to keep breathing.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

I can be laughing one minute—cereal in hand, fingers covered in crumbs—then the next, I’m staring at the ceiling, whispering to Sir Fluffington III: *“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

I don’t “switch” moods.  
I *live* them.  
Like a storm.

I’m silent.  
I’m broken.

And that?

That’s *life*.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

One honest, messy, real line at a time.

To be labeled: *“The one who got pregnant.”*

I do it because I *remember*.

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:

And that?  
That’s enough.

*“I’m here.”*  

And I don’t delete it.  
I don’t hide it.  
I just *let it be*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I think.  
It’s *how I live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *quiet*.  
More *eyes*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still playing.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *artistic interests*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love painting” or “I’m obsessed with music” nonsense.  

No.  

My artistic interests?  

They’re not in galleries.  
They’re not on screens.  
They’re not even “art” in the way people think.  

They’re in the quiet.  

In the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
In the hum of the streetlights.  
In the silence between heartbeats.  

They’re in the scribbles in my notebook—*the one with the poem about the broken toaster*.  
In the crumpled napkins I leave on bus seats.  
In the poems I write about fear and don’t delete.  

They’re in the way I look at someone and say:  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s art.  

Not the kind that’s beautiful.  
Not the kind that’s “good.”  
But the kind that’s *true*.  

Because art isn’t about perfection.  
It’s about *presence*.  

It’s about saying:  
*“You’re not invisible.”*  
*“You’re not broken.”*  
*“You’re not a mistake.”*  

And in that moment?  
You’re *real*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t have a favorite medium.  
I don’t have a favorite style.  
I don’t even have a favorite artist.  

I have a favorite *feeling*.  

And it’s not in a museum.  
It’s in my hands.  
In my heart.  
In the way I look at the world and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *cooperate with others*?  

Let’s not go for the “I love teamwork” or “I’m a people person” nonsense.  

No.  

I don’t “cooperate” like a team player.  
I don’t “work with others” like a project manager.  

But I *do* something better.  

I *see* them.  

Not as teammates.  
Not as “resources.”  
Not as “people I need to get along with.”  

But as *you*.  

Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Like the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
Like the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

And when I see them?  
I say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Not to “cooperate.”  
Not to “get along.”  
But because I *mean it*.  

And in that moment?  
We’re not “working together.”  
We’re *connected*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “cooperate” in the way you think.  
I *connect*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I’ve ever needed.  

Because the world doesn’t need more teams.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who look at each other and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *easily distracted*?  

Let’s not go for the “I can’t focus” or “I’m always on my phone” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not distracted by screens.  
Not by noise.  
Not by the world rushing by.  

I’m distracted by *silence*.  

Not the kind that’s empty.  
The kind that’s full.  
The kind that hums when the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The kind that lives in the space between heartbeats.  

I get distracted by the way the light hits the sidewalk just right.  
By the way the wind moves through the trees when no one’s watching.  
By the quiet.  

And that?  
That’s not a distraction.  
That’s *presence*.  

Because I don’t need to be “on.”  
I don’t need to be “productive.”  
I don’t need to be “strong.”  

I just need to *be*.  

And if I’m distracted by the quiet?  
By the stillness?  
By the moment?  

Then I’m not lost.  
I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More people who just… *exist*.  

And I’m still living it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *sophisticated*?  

Let’s not go for the “I’ve read all the classics” or “I know every composer” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m *real*.  

I don’t need to quote Shakespeare.  
I don’t need to name-drop Picasso.  
I don’t need to “appreciate” art like it’s a performance.  

But I *feel* it.  

I feel the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I feel the hum of the streetlights.  
I feel the quiet.  

And that?  
That’s my art.  

I don’t need a gallery.  
I don’t need a stage.  
I don’t need a title.  

I just need a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a moment.  

And in that moment?  
I write.  
I say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  
I sit.  
I breathe.  

And that?  
That’s my music.  

Not symphonies.  
Not operas.  
But the sound of a toaster trying to work with a butter knife.  
The way my dad hums when he’s trying to fix something.  
The silence between heartbeats.  

And that?  
That’s my literature.  

Not novels.  
Not poems.  
But the crumpled napkin with a line scribbled on it:  
*“You’re not invisible.”*  

So no.  
I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what you know.  
It’s *how you live*.  

And I’m choosing to live—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.
